column3:
Concept ACK

Are there other places where the vendor name is used? For ex. the transaction list?
> Are there other places where the vendor name is used? For ex. the transaction list?\n\nAFAIK, no. @luke-jr might know as he was the one that pointed this out to me.

> AFAIK, no. luke-jr might know as he was the one that pointed this out to me.\n\nI checked: you're right, the only place outside of paymentrequestplus / paymentserver and the tests where the `getMerchant` method is used is here.
Concept ACK
Now, we need to find someone that has actual paid payment requests in their wallet to test this :smile:
Concept ACK
I think for testing, a simple option is @gavinandresen php script: https://github.com/gavinandresen/paymentrequest

For testing, I made an account on https://test.bitpay.com/ and created testnet payment requests there. It says you have to "verify" your account before you can make any payment requests, but for the testing site, you can enter pretty much anything and it will be accepted (except for the email, you have to use a valid email and verify it). Or you can try it out on mainnet using https://bitpay.com/d

Tested fc295e42071a82955c35d90792a9cbd127ca2859 works for me on transactions I made via BIP70 back in 2015.

![2019-09-14-16_39_16_397011134](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61096/64915938-55c50500-d70e-11e9-8111-a6eca6d63245.png)
Thanks for doing some "real world" testing @harding.

Concept ACK.

Tested fc295e4 on macOS 10.14 without BIP70 support by looking at some BitPay transactions from late 2018. It shows the merchant with "(Certificate was not verified)"

However when I test with BIP70 support it doesn't show the merchant. That doesn't work on master either.

A test case for `GetPaymentRequestMerchant` would be nice.

> However when I test with BIP70 support it doesn't show the merchant. That doesn't work on master either.\n\nPresumably the certificate is no longer valid. I believe they have a new certificate since earlier this year, so the old one expired and thus the merchant name isn't being shown now.

>  certificate is no longer valid. I believe they have a new certificate since earlier this year, so the old one expired and thus the merchant name isn't being shown now.\n\nHehe so this actually tends to work more reliably because it doesn't check the signature. Which is fine as it was (presumably) checked at the time the payment was made, which is what counts.

@achow101 Can you do the small comment correction please ^^\n\nIf not, this will be merged nevertheless in the course of today or tomorrow before the 0.19 split-off. It's more desirable to have this with a comment typo than not at all.
ACK 85973bcc44f60fe3bbc952557ebf578dd4c475d2

I have a couple of payments to bitpay in my wallet. In Bitcoin Core 0.18.1 the merchant information wasn't displayed at all for either of them. When I viewed the transaction details I would see this in the debug.log:

    PaymentRequestPlus::getMerchant: Payment request: certificate expired or not yet active

The certificate was valid from 2017-03-23 18:22:00.000 UTC to 2019-04-25 19:11:00

@dooglus Thanks for checking. Yes it was a bug that the certificate-checking for transactions used the current date, instead of the date of the transaction (also, verifying it once at payment would have been good enough, no need to do so every time details are viewed).
Please, factor this out to a function at least :smile:
Put it into a function and cleaned up this for loop and if block a bit.
thanks !
This will change Message,Message,Merchant,Merchant into Message,Merchant,Message,Merchant.\n\nIs that intentional? Probably should be in a separate commit...
Does it really matter that much that the order is changed?\n\nThe only reason I changed it is because it looked funny that there were two loops in a row over the same vector.
Should be `PaymentRequest` :)
Done
